utterances: But also, it does speak to how far we've come.
You don't go into a newsroom anymore and find just three people of color - I might footnote that there were no women among that group.
But in any case, this was a brother who humanized Timothy McVeigh.
You know, he actually - and the only journalist to have an interview with Timothy McVeigh.
He was one of the first to get down to the Gulf Coast after Katrina hit New Orleans.
His profile on Lena Horn - I have tape somewhere - which is like - phenomenal.

And the most recent work, you know, looking at the Duke Case.

I mean for all of our mixed feelings about race and gender in that Duke Case, what Ed Bradley did, as a journalist that he is - was - is to look at that case, not as an African-American man but as someone who was wondering about some of the holes that exist in this prosecution.

And he was always very gracious to people.
NABJ, of course, gave him a lifetime achievement award last year and the NAACP, among others, have talked about just a tremendous contribution he made.

NABJ, of course, the National Association of Black Journalists.

- I'll go wherever you want me to go.

I mean I want you to give your thoughts but one thing that always struck me about him was his demeanor and his style.
You know, he had a little earring and people talked about that for a while.
He was always so pulled together but in a way that he wanted to be.
And he's not afraid to be himself.
Exactly.
And what I always admired about him - I admired that, that he was not afraid to be himself.
I admired the fact that he was not ashamed to be a black man in the world and wasn't pushy about it, and was not ashamed to be himself and liked being himself.
And also what I like, of course he's probably the most famous graduate at Cheyney has ever had - University.
, Or or probably, any historically black institution - he is among those.

But I also like the fact that in every field, there's got to be somebody who is the first person to prove to people who don't believe black people can do things, that they can do them and do them as elegantly and as well and as competently as anybody else, and without really making waves in public as an example.
And that's what is path-breaking.
And he was an excellent, outstanding journalist - as somebody who's kicked around, being a journalist when I was younger, myself.
The guy was amazing, and there's nobody in the field who can say that he was not amazing.
And so that is the reason why he was a path-breaker for so many others.

You know, I want to kind of merge this with another thing that's on our radar, which is that the Los Angeles Times editor Dean Baquet was forced out of his position following a dispute with the Tribune Company over cost cuts.
And although I think it was you, Julianne, who said, you know, it's a reminder of how far we've come.
At the same time, you know, the news business - which, you know, I'm certainly in and you all are in, at least on same some level - is not a - it's not an easy place to be in at this point in time.
It's - there's a lot of changes going on.
And African-American's kind of fortunes - we go up and down with the fortunes of the business.

So, do we really think and you know, I guess, anyone can chime inn on this -you know, do we really think that we have a solid grounding in having black journalists where we need to be in the business?.
You know, African-American people will never have solid grounding in this country until we move closer to that the total picture of economic justice.

But I would say in this era of corporate consolidation, which is part of what's happening in the industry, Farai, as you very well know, the question that has to be raised is how many profits are enough profits?
I mean the news business is posting roughly 10 percent profits, which used to be considered a reasonable way rate of return.

But when you see Apple posting, you know, 90 percent profit and Google posting a 120 percent profit - if a news organization is part of a larger corporation, whose total goal is profit maximization, then you'll really never get the news.
And all these other sort of independent stuff, the 24-hour cable cycle, which is really not about news gathering, it's just about regurgitation.
These bloggers who have in such - you know, bloggers bring a lot to the table.
All of us have had our flirtation and - in your case, Farai, some pioneering work with blogging.
But the fact is that, you know, you're borrowing the news gathering function from other folks.
So that key function of putting information out there, as a function I think is being overlooked in this rush of profit maximization.
